name: tilia-mongolica
country-or-region-of-origin: North China and far eastern Russia
wildlife-value: The flowers attract bees and other insects.
particularly-resistant-to-insects/diseas: This tree shows resistance to aphids.
edibility: The young leaves and shoots may be eaten raw or cooked.  Tea is made from flowers.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: The fruit is a grayish nutlet. It is obovoid, leathery, hairy, and is 6-8 mm in size. The nutlet has a long strap-like bract.
flower-description: The flowers are fragrant pale yellow to creamy colored blossoms that hang in clusters.  There are 6-12 flowers per cluster. The clusters hang from a long strapped bract. The ovary is hairy, and the style is glabrous.
leaf-description: The leaves are simple, ovate, and 3-5 lobed with serrated margins. The leaf color is dark green in the summer with paler undersides. The fall color is mild yellow.  The leaves measure 2-3 inches in length and width.
bark-description: The bark is grayish and irregularly exfoliates.
stem-description: The stems are glabrous, and the winter buds are hairless.
uses: The inner bark's fiber is used to make mats, shoes, and coarse cloth.  The wood may be used to make broom handles and piano-sounding boards.
